content.source_1: Solar energy is classified as a renewable energy resource because the sun’s radiation is naturally replenished on human timescales.
content.source_2: Fossil fuels are nonrenewable energy resources formed from ancient organic matter over geological timescales.
content.source_3: A given resource cannot be both renewable and nonrenewable at the same time.
content.source_4: Manufacturing most solar photovoltaic panels today involves mining, smelting (e.g., silicon, aluminum, copper), and transport processes that are commonly powered by fossil fuels.
content.source_5: In many power systems, natural-gas-fired plants are used to balance the variability of solar generation, supplying electricity when sunlight is insufficient.
content.source_6: Fossil fuels are combustible hydrocarbons—such as coal, petroleum (oil), and natural gas—that release energy when burned.
